text: I assume that page will eventually document integrating the Julia VS Code extension with Julia's concept of environments (<https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/code-loading/#Environments>; <https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/v1.1/environments/>). The simplest way to get started with this is to open an existing project (with a `Project.toml` file) or a blank directory in VS Code, then execute the extension's `Julia: Activate This Environment` command. This will make your code in the VS Code editor run in a local project environment with separately managed dependencies from the rest of your system.

text: Since you mentioned Docker, it's pretty orthogonal to the goals of the Julia VS Code extension. I'd suggest getting used to using the Julia extension without Docker unless you absolutely need it for some reason (and even then, Docker is probably overkill).  Later, try to get used to using VS Code and Docker together using that link above, separately from Julia. When you have a handle of both and decide you need to use them together, you'll know which extension to troubleshoot
